articles.headline: ‘They’re Just Going to Let Me Die?’ One Woman’s Abortion Odyssey
articles.snippet: Madison Underwood was thrilled to learn she was pregnant. But when a rare defect in the developing fetus threatened her life, she was thrust into post-Roe chaos.
articles.abstract: Madison Underwood was thrilled to learn she was pregnant. But when a rare defect in the developing fetus threatened her life, she was thrust into post-Roe chaos.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn. — Madison Underwood was lying on the ultrasound table, nearly 19 weeks pregnant, when the doctor came in to say her abortion had been canceled.

articles.headline: U.S. Warns China Not to Turn Pelosi’s Expected Trip to Taiwan Into a ‘Crisis’
articles.snippet: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a longtime China hawk, has not confirmed that she plans to visit Taiwan, but all indications suggest that she will make a stop on the self-governing island without prior announcement.
articles.abstract: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, a longtime China hawk, has not confirmed that she plans to visit Taiwan, but all indications suggest that she will make a stop on the self-governing island without prior announcement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Nancy Pelosi’s Taiwan visit.

articles.headline: Ukraine Ships Grain at Last. It Will Take Far More to Slow Global Hunger.
articles.snippet: The departure of a grain-filled vessel from Odesa was hailed as a victory against global hunger. But experts say the crisis is so big that no single advance can reverse it.
articles.abstract: The departure of a grain-filled vessel from Odesa was hailed as a victory against global hunger. But experts say the crisis is so big that no single advance can reverse it.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — In the Horn of Africa, villagers trek for days across dust-blown wastelands to escape drought-induced famine. In cities from Syria to Central America, families go to bed hungry. In Afghanistan, starving children stream into hospitals.

articles.headline: U.S. Drone Strike Kills Ayman al-Zawahri, Top Qaeda Leader
articles.snippet: The strike, carried out over the weekend, was the first attack since American forces left Afghanistan last year.
articles.abstract: The strike, carried out over the weekend, was the first attack since American forces left Afghanistan last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American drone strike killed Ayman al-Zawahri, a key plotter of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks who took over as the leader of Al Qaeda after Osama bin Laden’s death, at an urban safe house in Afghanistan, President Biden announced on Monday night.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: As Russia Threatens Europe’s Energy, Ukraine Braces for a Hard Winter
articles.snippet: “Our goal is survival,” says the mayor of Lviv, as residents stockpile timber and ironworkers churn out wood-burning stoves.
articles.abstract: “Our goal is survival,” says the mayor of Lviv, as residents stockpile timber and ironworkers churn out wood-burning stoves.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a thickly forested park bordered by apartment blocks and a playground, a dozen workers were busy on a recent day with chain saws and axes, felling trees, cutting logs and chopping them into firewood to be stashed in concealed sheds around Lviv, the largest city in western Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

articles.headline: As Pelosi Arrives, Quiet Defiance in Taiwan
articles.snippet: Public nonchalance about the tensions over Nancy Pelosi belies a political reality: Many are tired of China’s threats and crave American support.
articles.abstract: Public nonchalance about the tensions over Nancy Pelosi belies a political reality: Many are tired of China’s threats and crave American support.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Nancy Pelosi’s Taiwan visit.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur, Chris Horton and Amy Chang Chien

articles.headline: The Crypto Market Crashed. They’re Still Buying Bitcoin.
articles.snippet: Hard-core Bitcoin evangelists are making the case that Bitcoin differs from the unstable crypto projects that sent the market into a tailspin.
articles.abstract: Hard-core Bitcoin evangelists are making the case that Bitcoin differs from the unstable crypto projects that sent the market into a tailspin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cory Klippsten started issuing warnings about the cryptocurrency market in March. The digital coin Luna, Mr. Klippsten tweeted, was a scam, run by an entrepreneur with “major Elizabeth Holmes vibes.” The newfangled crypto bank Celsius Network was a “massive blowup risk,” he said.

articles.headline: The Illegal Airstrips Bringing Toxic Mining to Brazil’s Indigenous Land
articles.snippet: The Times identified hundreds of airstrips that bring criminal mining operations to the most remote corners of the Amazon.
articles.abstract: The Times identified hundreds of airstrips that bring criminal mining operations to the most remote corners of the Amazon.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Times identified hundreds of airstrips that bring criminal mining operations to the most remote corners of the Amazon.
articles.byline: By Manuela Andreoni, Blacki Migliozzi, Pablo Robles and Denise Lu

articles.headline: What Twitter’s Subpoenas Say About Its Plan to Fight Elon Musk in Court
articles.snippet: Twitter has sent out requests for information from the banks that are backing the billionaire’s purchase, which he is trying to walk away from.
articles.abstract: Twitter has sent out requests for information from the banks that are backing the billionaire’s purchase, which he is trying to walk away from.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter has sent dozens of subpoenas in recent days to the banks and investors that were backing Elon Musk in his bid to acquire the company, while also seeking more information about well-known technology industry personalities who are considered close to Mr. Musk.

articles.headline: For the Taliban, a New Era of Isolation Has Arrived
articles.snippet: The group has promised moderation even while reinstituting its harsh rule of Afghanistan. Now, the revelation that the Taliban were sheltering Al Qaeda’s leader is likely to harden support for sanctions.
articles.abstract: The group has promised moderation even while reinstituting its harsh rule of Afghanistan. Now, the revelation that the Taliban were sheltering Al Qaeda’s leader is likely to harden support for sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hours after an American drone strike killed the leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, in downtown Kabul, Taliban security forces rushed to seal off the site. Green tarps were thrown over destroyed windows. Checkpoints were put up, and shops were closed.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Profits Slump at CNN as Ratings Plummet
articles.snippet: The network is on a pace to drop below $1 billion in profit for the first time in years, according to people familiar with its operations, amid steep declines in TV viewership.
articles.abstract: The network is on a pace to drop below $1 billion in profit for the first time in years, according to people familiar with its operations, amid steep declines in TV viewership.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the first moves the newly formed Warner Bros. Discovery made when it took over CNN was shutting down CNN+, the nascent streaming service that was touted as the network’s bridge to the future.
